SourceText: About @global.parent_app
text: About @global.parent_app
note: The string @global.parent_app should not be translated.

SourceText:
@global.parent_app was developed by Parenting for Lifelong Health (PLH) – a worldwide collaboration between parenting experts from UNICEF, the WHO and Universities in South Africa and the UK, as well as African NGOs and families and teens all across Africa. Parents and teens worked with us on the app and helped to ensure it is easy-to-use, fun and engaging. Some of the content in this app, like suggestions of activities and illustrated stories, were created with parents and teens to make sure it fits families’ needs.

Parenting for Lifelong Health (PLH) is committed to supporting free and shareable parenting materials and programmes, to support parents worldwide to promote the well-being of their children.
text:

Some of the content in this app, like suggestions of activities and illustrated stories, were created with parents and teens to make sure it fits families’ needs.

Parenting for Lifelong Health (PLH) is committed to supporting free and shareable parenting materials and programmes, to support parents worldwide to promote the well-being of their children.

SourceText: The first time my mother asked me if I wanted to spend time with her, I told her to leave me alone because I was in the middle of a game. But she insisted like she always does. I said she could watch me playing if that's what she wanted. After a few minutes she started asking me questions about the game. It was annoying at the beginning, but after a while I was happy that she was finally interested in what I was doing. She even gave it a try!
text: The first time my mother asked me if I wanted to spend time with her, I told her to leave me alone because I was in the middle of a game. But she insisted like she always does. I said she could watch me playing if that's what she wanted. After a few minutes she started asking me questions about the game. It was annoying at the beginning, but after a while I was happy that she was finally interested in what I was doing. She even gave it a try!

SourceText: My father told me I’m playing too much basketball after school, so we must set a family rule. He promised we'll think about a solution together, so we both feel good about it. I didn't believe it's possible but said, “OK, let's try”. We negotiated and agreed that the rule will be playing basketball is allowed after doing homework and until family dinner. It is hard for me to see my friends playing after school, so I'm doing my best to finish homework first and join them. I also have now the whole evening to do other things I want after the family dinner like watching basketball in the NBA.

It is hard for me to see my friends playing after school, so I'm doing my best to finish homework first and join them. I also have now the whole evening to do other things I want after the family dinner like watching basketball in the NBA.

SourceText: Having a specific time to do this helps me to remember.

SourceText: With a routine, my teen and I can both keep our schedule free.
text: With a routine, my teen and I can both keep our schedule free.

SourceText: Spending time with my teen every day helps to build trust with them/him/her.
text: Spending time with my teen every day helps to build trust with them/him/her.

SourceText: Ah yes, even 10 minutes together makes a big difference – that makes it easy to schedule it in, next to your work and chores!
text: Ah yes, even 10 minutes together makes a big difference – that makes it easy to schedule it in, next to your work and chores!

SourceText: Letting my teen choose what to do builds their confidence.
text: Letting my teen choose what to do builds their confidence.

SourceText: If my teen chooses, s/he is more likely to want to spend time together.
text: If my teen chooses, s/he is more likely to want to spend time together.

SourceText: Letting my teen choose shows that I care about his/her interests.
text: Letting my teen choose shows that I care about his/her interests.

SourceText: By accepting my teen’s suggestions, I show that I listen to him/her.
text: By accepting my teen’s suggestions, I show that I listen to him/her.

SourceText: Saying something nice about my teen’s choice helps them feel valued.
text: Saying something nice about my teen’s choice helps them feel valued.

SourceText: So true! And if our teens choose, they are encouraged to also take responsibility in other areas of their lives.
text: So true! And if our teens choose, they are encouraged to also take responsibility in other areas of their lives.

SourceText: By preventing interruptions, I show my teen that s/he is most important.
text: By preventing interruptions, I show my teen that s/he is most important.

SourceText: Even if I can’t join my teen’s activity, like sports, I can still cheer them on.
text: Even if I can’t join my teen’s activity, like sports, I can still cheer them on.

SourceText: When I pay attention, I can learn so much about my teen’s interests, views and abilities.
text: When I pay attention, I can learn so much about my teen’s interests, views and abilities.

SourceText: Yes! If we give our teens our full attention, they will more likely do the same for us the next time we ask them for something!
text: Yes! If we give our teens our full attention, they will more likely do the same for us the next time we ask them for something!

SourceText:
Many parents experience challenges in having one-on-one time with their teens. 

Here are the top 8 challenges parents told us they experience when planning or spending one-on-one time with their teen. If you experienced one of these or are afraid that you will, tap it to get a possible solution. You can tap and explore other challenges afterwards.
text:
Many parents experience challenges in having one-on-one time with their teens. 

Here are the top 8 challenges parents told us they experience when planning or spending one-on-one time with their teen. If you experienced one of these or are afraid that you will, tap it to get a possible solution. You can tap and explore other challenges afterwards.

SourceText: Did you have any challenges when trying to spend time with your teen?
text: Did you have any challenges when trying to spend time with your teen?

SourceText: What challenge did you have when trying to spend time with your teen?
text: What challenge did you have when trying to spend time with your teen?

SourceText: I don’t have enough time.
text: I don’t have enough time.

SourceText: My teen does not want to spend time with me.
text: My teen does not want to spend time with me.

SourceText: My teen only wants to watch TV or play on his/her phone.
text: My teen only wants to watch TV or play on his/her phone.

SourceText: My teen wants to do things that are not safe or that cost money.
text: My teen wants to do things that are not safe or that cost money.

SourceText: My teen wants to do things that I cannot physically do.
text: My teen wants to do things that I cannot physically do.

SourceText: My teen chose a competitive activity. I won and s/he got angry.
text: My teen chose a competitive activity. I won and s/he got angry.

SourceText: I struggled to end the one-on-one time.
text: I struggled to end the one-on-one time.

SourceText: All my children want one-on-one time with me at the same time.
text: All my children want one-on-one time with me at the same time.

SourceText: Yes, it can be really hard to find time during the day, with work, chores, and everything else.
text: Yes, it can be really hard to find time during the day, with work, chores, and everything else.

SourceText: Sorry that you struggled with that. It can make us feel bad if our children do not want to spend one-on-one time with us.
text: Sorry that you struggled with that. It can make us feel bad if our children do not want to spend one-on-one time with us.

SourceText: Think of a time when my teen is more open to me, like in the morning or right before bedtime.
text: Think of a time when my teen is more open to me, like in the morning or right before bedtime.

SourceText: Sit next to my teen when they are doing something they enjoy and show interest in what they like.
text: Sit next to my teen when they are doing something they enjoy and show interest in what they like.

SourceText: Do something fun with the whole family.
text: Do something fun with the whole family.

SourceText: Great! Picking a time when your teen is more talkative will help them to respond well to your attempt to connect.
text: Great! Picking a time when your teen is more talkative will help them to respond well to your attempt to connect.

SourceText: Nice! Watching your teen’s favourite T.V. show or sports match together will show them that you care. Just be patient; they will open up to you over time!
text: Nice! Watching your teen’s favourite T.V. show or sports match together will show them that you care. Just be patient; they will open up to you over time!

SourceText: Perfect! Sometimes it can be easier to start with spending time with the whole family. That way your teen can get more comfortable with spending one-on-one time with you over time.
text: Perfect! Sometimes it can be easier to start with spending time with the whole family. That way your teen can get more comfortable with spending one-on-one time with you over time.

SourceText: Sorry that you had that challenge. Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Well done for being patient with your teen!
text: Sorry that you had that challenge. Children often want to spend time watching T.V. or playing with a gadget. Well done for being patient with your teen!

SourceText: Suggest fun things my teen and I could do together.
text: Suggest fun things my teen and I could do together.

SourceText: Find something educational to do with my teen on the gadget.
text: Find something educational to do with my teen on the gadget.

SourceText: Ask my teen to show me how their phone/gadget works.
text: Ask my teen to show me how their phone/gadget works.

SourceText: That's perfect! If you need inspiration, here are some ideas from other families of what you could do together. Remember, let your teen choose.
text: That's perfect! If you need inspiration, here are some ideas from other families of what you could do together. Remember, let your teen choose.

SourceText: Wonderful!  There are lots of fun and educational apps on phones that you can explore together. Ask questions, show interest, and remember to say something nice.
text: Wonderful!  There are lots of fun and educational apps on phones that you can explore together. Ask questions, show interest, and remember to say something nice.

SourceText: Nice! Teens love it when you show interest in their gadget and when they get to explain something they know to you. This is a great starting point!
text: Nice! Teens love it when you show interest in their gadget and when they get to explain something they know to you. This is a great starting point!

SourceText: You are not alone here. Many parents sometimes have this challenge, too. One-on-one time should always be safe, and it does not have to cost a thing!
text: You are not alone here. Many parents sometimes have this challenge, too. One-on-one time should always be safe, and it does not have to cost a thing!

SourceText: Explain to my teen why their suggestion is not safe or possible and ask them for other ideas.
text: Explain to my teen why their suggestion is not safe or possible and ask them for other ideas.

SourceText: Suggest other fun activities that we could do together.
text: Suggest other fun activities that we could do together.

SourceText: Awesome! It is very important that your teen understands why you cannot do the activity that they suggested. Ask them for other ideas!
text: Awesome! It is very important that your teen understands why you cannot do the activity that they suggested. Ask them for other ideas!

SourceText: This is perfect! If you need any inspiration, you can find suggestions for activities @data.parent_centre.relax_and_activities.location_text. Remember, let your teen choose the activity!

text: Sorry to hear this. Our teens may be disappointed if we cannot do what they want to do, like playing sports or doing other physically demanding activities. But remember, what is most important is that we spend time with them. That looks different for everyone!

SourceText: Watch my teen do the activity and cheer them on.
text: Watch my teen do the activity and cheer them on.

SourceText: Suggest other fun activities we can do together.
text: Suggest other fun activities we can do together.

SourceText: Wonderful! Even if you are watching instead of doing the activity together, you can show your interest by describing and praising what your teen is doing!
text: Wonderful! Even if you are watching instead of doing the activity together, you can show your interest by describing and praising what your teen is doing!

SourceText: That’s perfect! If you need any inspiration, you can find suggestions for activities @data.parent_centre.relax_and_activities.location_text. Remember, let your teen choose the activity!

SourceText: Suggest other activities that we can do together instead of against each other.
text: Suggest other activities that we can do together instead of against each other.

SourceText: Play the activity in teams, so I can encourage my teen if our team loses.
text: Play the activity in teams, so I can encourage my teen if our team loses.

SourceText: Remember, let your teen choose! You can find suggestions for activities you could do with your teen @data.parent_centre.relax_and_activities.location_text, if you need it.

text: If you and your teen are in the same team, you can help them manage their emotions if your team loses.

SourceText: Yes, the end of one-on-one time can sometimes be difficult.
text: Yes, the end of one-on-one time can sometimes be difficult.

SourceText: Say to my teen, “We have one minute before the end of one-on-one time today”, so my teen is prepared.
text: Say to my teen, “We have one minute before the end of one-on-one time today”, so my teen is prepared.

SourceText: Inform my teen of how much time I have for one-on-one time and ask them to keep track on a clock or watch.
text: Inform my teen of how much time I have for one-on-one time and ask them to keep track on a clock or watch.

SourceText: Plan one-on-one time right before another activity that my teen enjoys.
text: Plan one-on-one time right before another activity that my teen enjoys.

SourceText: Wonderful! By giving your teen a heads-up, the end of one-on-one time will not come as a surprise. Also, you can remind your teen that you will spend time together again tomorrow.
text: Wonderful! By giving your teen a heads-up, the end of one-on-one time will not come as a surprise. Also, you can remind your teen that you will spend time together again tomorrow.

SourceText: Great! That way your teen has the responsibility to monitor the time and will be aware when time is almost up. Remind them that you will spend time together again tomorrow.
text: Great! That way your teen has the responsibility to monitor the time and will be aware when time is almost up. Remind them that you will spend time together again tomorrow.

SourceText: Wonderful! If you spend time together right before dinner, you can happily say, “one-on-one time is over. Let’s get ready for dinner with the rest of the family!”
text: Wonderful! If you spend time together right before dinner, you can happily say, “one-on-one time is over. Let’s get ready for dinner with the rest of the family!”

SourceText: Many parents face this. It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with our teens when we have more than one child.
text: Many parents face this. It can be difficult to spend one-on-one time with our teens when we have more than one child.

text: Ask another adult or older sibling to look after the younger children during the one-on-one time with my teen.

text: Think of a time when the other children are not around and spend time with my teen then.

text: Plan one-on-one time in a place other than at home.

SourceText: Perfect! This way, you can give your undivided attention to your teen, so they feel valued and loved.
text: Perfect! This way, you can give your undivided attention to your teen, so they feel valued and loved.

SourceText: Great! You can try spending time with your teen when the other children have already gone to bed, or are playing outside.
text: Great! You can try spending time with your teen when the other children have already gone to bed, or are playing outside.

SourceText:
When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. 

Next time your teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
text:
When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better.

SourceText: My teen got very angry with me after I gave the consequence.

SourceText:
When your teen gets angry, you might need to walk away until you are both calm. 

Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. Listen to your teen’s explanation, and make sure to give a “Safety Amnesty” if they broke a rule in order to stay safe.

If your teen keeps breaking rules, you might need to spend more positive time with them. 

Try to keep going with your other goals  – like self-care, one-on-one time, and praise. All these skills will help your teen feel more loved and secure… and you less stressed!

Brainstorm some calm consequences with them that could help them understand that they have done something wrong. These will be more effective and will set positive examples!

text: Did you experience any of these challenges when sharing how you feel with your teen?

SourceText: What was difficult for you about sharing how you feel with your teen?
text: What was difficult for you about sharing how you feel with your teen?

SourceText: I was afraid my teen would think I was weak.
text: I was afraid my teen would think I was weak.

SourceText: Sharing feelings, especially the difficult ones, sets an important example for your teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
text: Sharing feelings, especially the difficult ones, sets an important example for your teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.

SourceText: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings.
text: I felt uncomfortable about naming specific difficult feelings.

SourceText: Being specific is not rude or insensitive - it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. Feelings like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is handle our emotions well by taking a few deep breaths before responding.
text: Being specific is not rude or insensitive - it really helps others to understand you clearly and this prevents confusion in the family. Feelings like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is handle our emotions well by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

SourceText: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings.
text: My teen felt uncomfortable when I shared my feelings.

SourceText: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!
text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it and keep showing a good example by observing and sharing your feelings. Over time, your teen will learn to do the same, and they will feel even more loved and cared for!

SourceText: When I shared my feelings, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable.
text: When I shared my feelings, my teen asked many questions, which made me uncomfortable.

SourceText: Sharing feelings helps your teen to be aware and learn to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, “I am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
text: Sharing feelings helps your teen to be aware and learn to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later by saying, “I am feeling angry/stressed now. Could you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.

SourceText: I was too stressed or angry to try sharing my feelings – I prefer to be alone when I feel like that.
text: I was too stressed or angry to try sharing my feelings – I prefer to be alone when I feel like that.

SourceText: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time to explain later, when you feel calmer, so that everyone can understand.
text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time to explain later, when you feel calmer, so that everyone can understand.

SourceText:
* Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”
* Ask each other, “What difficulty did you face today?”
* Ask each other, “How can I help you?”
* Try to do this together every day; it could be when you are eating dinner together or before you go to bed.
text:
* Ask each other, “What made you happy today?”
* Ask each other, “What difficulty did you face today?”
* Ask each other, “How can I help you?”
* Try to do this together every day; it could be when you are eating dinner together or before you go to bed.

SourceText:
* You can’t always travel, but you can always dream! Ask your teen these questions:
* Where would you want to travel to? How long would you be away? What would you pack? What would you do on your trip? What would you see?
* Look at a map together or draw one.
* Choose a country that your teen has never heard of and learn more about the country.

SourceText: You and your teenager can plan a guestlist of the famous people you’d most like to invite to your party. You can each have five people – they can be from the past or from the present time. Who would you invite? And would your guests get on well together?
text: You and your teenager can plan a guestlist of the famous people you’d most like to invite to your party. You can each have five people – they can be from the past or from the present time. Who would you invite? And would your guests get on well together?

SourceText:
* Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
* It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example: I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing. 
* Say them to your teenager and ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
* Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
* Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?
text:
* Think of three statements about yourself. Two must be true and one must be a lie.
* It might help to think of wishes, dreams, experiences at school, likes or dislikes. For example: I hate bananas, my favourite subject is science, and I really wish I could sing. 
* Say them to your teenager and ask them to guess which one is a lie. 
* Did they guess correctly? Was it a surprise?
* Now ask them to do the same. Did you learn something new about each other?

SourceText: Tell your teenager something about when you were a teenager yourself. What things didn’t exist then? Phones with internet? What did you do for fun? What did you worry about? Don’t worry if they don’t tell you something in return – what’s important is that they listen and remember. Sometimes our teenagers forget that their parents are people too!
text: Tell your teenager something about when you were a teenager yourself. What things didn’t exist then? Phones with internet? What did you do for fun? What did you worry about? Don’t worry if they don’t tell you something in return – what’s important is that they listen and remember. Sometimes our teenagers forget that their parents are people too!

SourceText:
* Think of a superpower. For example, going anywhere instantly, travelling in time, reading minds. 
* Ask your teen, “If you had the superpower to […], how would you use it?”
* Encourage them to give their superhero a name and act it out. 
* Now let your teen choose a superpower for you.
* Make sure you act out your superpower, too!

SourceText:
Have a conversation with your teen about something they like.

It can be about anything they choose to talk about: sports, friends, music, celebrities…

Try to listen to your teen and give them space to talk.

SourceText:
* Choose a storyteller to start making up a story.
* Story listeners can interrupt with a word at any time.
* Storyteller needs to fit that word in their story.
* When the story is finished, try with a different storyteller!

SourceText:
* Think of three different situations. For example, driving a car, sailing a boat or flying a plane.
* Say them to your teen and ask, “Which would you prefer?”
* Ask them why?
* Now think of three more situations or ask your teen to do it for you.

SourceText:
* Ask each other questions. They can be any questions about things you like or what you did today.
* The only rule is that you can’t answer “Yes”, “No” or “Maybe”.
* How long can you last? How creative can you get with your answers?
* Swap over and play again!

SourceText:
* First person says, “On Saturday, I am going to… (e.g., go to the park)”
* Second person adds to first person, “On Saturday, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend).
* Each person adds to the previous, trying to think of all of the fun things to do on Saturday.

SourceText:
* Start the story with “Once upon a time there was a…”
* Let your teen make up the next sentence.
* Then you make up a sentence.
* Take turns until you have a wonderful new story.
* Make sure to end the story on a positive note.
* Ask your teen what was their favourite part of the story!

SourceText:
* Ask your teen what kind of meal they would like to eat. 
* Prepare it together!    
* Let them have a turn at being the head chef – they lead, and you follow their instructions. 
* You can even help them to make a budget for the ingredients! 

Don’t think it will work? Ask your teens what THEY would like for you and them to do together. Let them lead. Relax. Have fun.

SourceText:
* Create a set of dance moves to your teen's favourite songs. 
* One person does a dance move and everyone else copies it.  
* Everyone takes turns being the leader. 
* Perform it for the household!
text:
* Create a set of dance moves to your teen's favourite songs. 
* One person does a dance move and everyone else copies it.  
* Everyone takes turns being the leader. 
* Perform it for the household!

SourceText:
* This game can be played in pairs or with many people in a group.
* Stand facing each other or in a circle. 
* One person leads first and everyone else copies them, trying to move exactly at the same time as the leader.
* Make sure the leader moves slowly enough for everyone else to follow! Explore moving different body parts and in different levels.
* After a while, switch who is leading. Give everyone a chance to lead.
* Try it with no leaders!

SourceText: Praise time! Look at your teen and praise them for one thing they are doing well! And when was the last time you praised yourself or another adult in your household? Try it!

SourceText:
* Think of a new skill you could learn together with your teen. For example, keeping a ball in the air or your foot, juggling, making soup?
* Take turns in trying the new skill out.
* Make sure to praise each other, and try to learn and play together!
text:

SourceText:
* Come up with three types of exercise together. For example, walking, jogging, soccer or dancing.
* Pick one together and try it out. 
* If you both like it, decide how often you are going to do it. Once or twice a week? Every morning?
* Together think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns in being the coach? Motivate each other with a small free reward?

* Together think of ways to make it even more fun. Can you jog to a certain point? Take turns in being the coach? Motivate each other with a small free reward?

SourceText:
* The first person gets to choose or sing a song.
* Everyone else must guess the name of the tune (to make it harder they can guess the singer).
* The first one to guess it right becomes the next leader.
text:

* The first one to guess it right becomes the next leader.

SourceText:
This game is best with at least 3 people.
* Start in a circle and pass one “snap” around the circle (or a “clap” if you cannot snap).
* You “snap” once to throw the “snap”, and once to catch it. Look at the person you are throwing it to.  
* The direction (up, down, straight, curved, rolling the ground) and force (hard, soft, medium) that you throw the snap should affect how the person catches it.  
* You can bounce the “snap”, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.  
* When everyone gets good at this, you can start moving around the room, still passing the “snap”.  
* Can you throw under the leg? Behind the back? Through your head? Intercept a pass? Have fun with the “snap”!

* You can bounce the “snap”, throw it in the air, and catch it a few times before passing it.

SourceText:
Choose a sport or exercise to do together. Decide on a schedule. Are you going to do it every day? For how long? 

Try it out for a week. At the end of the week, ask yourself and your family these questions:
* How is it going? 
* How did you feel at the start of the week? 
* How do you feel at the end of the week? 
* What can we do differently next week?

SourceText:
Take turns being the “leader”. Say the intro sentences to activate everyone. Then the “leader” gives an instruction and everyone does the activity as fast as possible:
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “Touch something red.” 
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “Jump up and down ten times.”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”

* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”

* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “Jump up and down ten times.”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “There’s a fire on the mountain!”        
* Together: “Run, run, run!”
* Leader: “Put the shoes in the shoe rack.”

SourceText:
This game is best when more than 2 people play.
* One person pretends to be doing something – for example, combing hair or making dinner. 
* Another person asks, “What are you doing?”
* The first person needs to say something that has nothing to do with combing hair, for example, “Tying my shoes.”  
* The second person then starts pretending to tie their shoes until a new person asks, “What are you doing?” 

The answer must always be something different than what you are actually doing!

SourceText:
Here's an activity to relax your body:  

Sit comfortably and close your eyes if you can.  
Imagine a golden ring scanning your body from your feet to your head.   
Pay attention as it moves up and down your body. Are there any areas that feel tense? Numb? Painful?   
Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.   
Do this for a few breaths.   

Open your eyes. How does your body feel now?

Focus on those areas for a moment. Breathe in to the area and when you breathe out, try to let go of any tension or pain.   
Do this for a few breaths.

SourceText:

Notice your connection with the ground beneath you.  
What parts of your body touch the ground? What parts of your body don’t?   
Notice where it feels warm and where it feels cool.  
Feel the ground underneath you supporting you. Let your body sink into the support of the ground.

Listen to the sounds inside and outside the room. Count them on your fingers. 
After ten seconds, how many fingers do you have up? What sounds did you hear? 

Try again for another ten seconds.  
Did you hear any new sounds? Did you hear any sounds inside your own body? 
Notice how you feel now.

SourceText:
Close your eyes.  

Do you every feel something so strongly that you want to run away from it?  

Instead of moving away from the feeling, let’s move towards it for a moment.  
It’s ok. Close your eyes if you feel comfortable. Take a deep breath.  

Become curious. Where are you feeling it in your body? Is it hot or cold? Hard or soft? Tight or loose?  
Ask yourself some questions. What is it telling me? What does it need? How can I be kind to myself right now?

SourceText:
Sit comfortably and close your eyes. 

Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?

Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. Say the following words silently to yourself:

May I be peaceful.
May I be safe.
May I be healthy.
May I be happy.
May there be love in my family.
May I feel loved.

SourceText: Take a moment to reflect on your experience. Notice if you feel any different.

SourceText:
Step 1. Close your eyes and take a deep breath. 

Step 2. Ask yourself, "What am I thinking?" Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative.
Notice how you are feeling emotionally. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Remind yourself that whatever you feel, it is okay.
Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.

Step 3. Focus on your breath. Feel your breath as it goes in and out. You can put a hand on your stomach and feel it rise and fall with each breath. Do this for about 10 breaths.

Step 4. Expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room. 

Step 5. Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different. When you are ready, open your eyes.

SourceText: Well done for Taking a Pause. You can do this anytime you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Children!

SourceText:
Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.

Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.

Relax your arms and let your arms to swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.

Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.

Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!

Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.

Take a moment to reflect on your experience.

SourceText:
Make a list of healthy activities that you like to do. Here are some suggestions:
* Listening to your favourite music
* Going for a walk (if allowed)
* Doing some exercise
* Drinking a cup of tea by yourself
* Calling up a friend
* Singing, dancing, praying, or reading
* Sitting in the sun with your eyes closed
* Watching your favourite T.V. show

Pick one and do it today!

SourceText: When you take care of yourself, you take care of your children. We all need to connect. Try to talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day. If it has been a while since you reached out to someone, do it now!

SourceText:

Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.

SourceText:
Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.

Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!

SourceText: Building a better relationship starts with spending time together - even 5 minutes a day makes a difference! At first, it can be hard to spend time together, as we are all busy and our teens can be in a bad mood sometimes. But spending even 5 minutes a day of focused time with your teen helps to build trust. Try asking your teen what they would like to do together. It can be fun and relaxing for you too!
text: Building a better relationship starts with spending time together - even 5 minutes a day makes a difference! At first, it can be hard to spend time together, as we are all busy and our teens can be in a bad mood sometimes. But spending even 5 minutes a day of focused time with your teen helps to build trust. Try asking your teen what they would like to do together. It can be fun and relaxing for you too!

SourceText: You can get more support on how to spend one-on-one time with your teen here:
text: You can get more support on how to spend one-on-one time with your teen here:

SourceText: All teenagers sometimes behave just horribly! One thing that can help with teenage behaviour is to praise them any time that they do something good – however small. Teens may not look like they want or seek your praise but they still really, really do.
text: All teenagers sometimes behave just horribly! One thing that can help with teenage behaviour is to praise them any time that they do something good – however small. Teens may not look like they want or seek your praise but they still really, really do.

SourceText: You can get more support here on how to encourage good behaviour through praising:

SourceText: Parenting stress is really high right now. We know exactly how overwhelming life can be. Doing something for yourself can reduce your stress. You deserve it! And when you feel overwhelmed, take back control over your body by taking five slow, deep breaths before responding. Lots of parents found this helpful.
text: Parenting stress is really high right now. We know exactly how overwhelming life can be. Doing something for yourself can reduce your stress. You deserve it! And when you feel overwhelmed, take back control over your body by taking five slow, deep breaths before responding. Lots of parents found this helpful.

SourceText: You are not alone. Money stress is so hard for parents. Try talking to your teen about how much money comes in and what you need to spend money on as a family each month. This can help them to understand why you cannot afford something they want. And when everyone understands where the money goes, it is easier to agree on where you can save together too!

This can help them to understand why you cannot afford something they want. And when everyone understands where the money goes, it is easier to agree on where you can save together too!

SourceText: You can get more support on how to budget and save here:

SourceText: Teens spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe - many parents worry about this. Try to start a conversation with your teen about safe and unsafe places in your community and online (you might need to try a few times). They may even know some you do not. This can start to help you make a plan together about how to stay safe.

SourceText:
Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our children never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.
text:
Being a parent can be so hard. Sometimes it feels like our children never listen to us.

But science shows that spending just a few minutes each day of focused one-on-one time with your teen helps build trust and love.

SourceText:
One-on-one time is when you focus on them, without TV or phones. Let them lead what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can do twenty minutes a day, but even five minutes a day is really good.
text:
One-on-one time is when you focus on them, without TV or phones. Let them lead what you do or talk about.

It is great if you can do twenty minutes a day, but even five minutes a day is really good.

SourceText:
Hello.

Our topic today is one-on-one time with our children.

It is important to spend time with our children so that they can get to understand us, and for us to get an opportunity to understand them. 

Remember, a family with good understanding live in harmony.

SourceText:
Teenagers often break rules. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are. 

Luckily, there are ways to discipline your teen without getting angry or using violence… and they work well!

Giving calm consequences helps teach our children responsibility for what they do – good and bad. 

Here are some examples - imagine you are the parent:
text:
Teenagers often break rules. Growing up is a difficult time when they are learning about who they are. 

Luckily, there are ways to discipline your teen without getting angry or using violence… and they work well!

Giving calm consequences helps teach our children responsibility for what they do – good and bad. 

Here are some examples - imagine you are the parent:

SourceText:
Calm consequences should be... 

FAIR: Not too harsh and you can actually do it 

IMMEDIATE: Give them as soon as possible 

CONSISTENT: The same consequence every time
text:
Calm consequences should be... 

FAIR: Not too harsh and you can actually do it 

IMMEDIATE: Give them as soon as possible 

CONSISTENT: The same consequence every time

SourceText:
Consequences are not quite the same as punishment: they give our teens a chance to learn responsibility for their actions.

And they are more controlled AND effective than hitting or shouting!
text:
Consequences are not quite the same as punishment: they give our teens a chance to learn responsibility for their actions.

And they are more controlled AND effective than hitting or shouting!

Consequences are more successful if you discuss and agree in advance with teens before you apply them.

And: consequences are not all negative… You can also agree on GOOD consequences for GOOD actions to see more positive behaviour!

text: EXPLAIN

SourceText:
Check you are both calm. Take a few breaths. Explain to your teen why you are concerned about their behaviour.

Explain the reasons why the rule mattered. You can share your feelings - it’s okay to say you are disappointed.
text:

SourceText: AGREE
text: AGREE

SourceText:
Plan consequences with your teen for following and not following the rule.

Ask for their ideas. Talk until you agree on something realistic.

Make a consequence for NOT following the rule and a privilege when they DO follow the rule.
text:
Plan consequences with your teen for following and not following the rule.

SourceText: ACT
text: ACT

SourceText: When your teen follows the rule, give praise and privileges!
text: When your teen follows the rule, give praise and privileges!

SourceText: They will feel respected and valued. Remember: The more we praise them, the more they will show that good behaviour!
text: They will feel respected and valued. Remember: The more we praise them, the more they will show that good behaviour!

SourceText: When your teen does not follow the rule, follow through with the consequence.
text: When your teen does not follow the rule, follow through with the consequence.

SourceText: When your teen breaks the rule, calmly give the consequence. This should be FAIR (not too harsh), IMMEDIATE (do it straight away) CONSISTENT (same every time).
text: When your teen breaks the rule, calmly give the consequence. This should be FAIR (not too harsh), IMMEDIATE (do it straight away) CONSISTENT (same every time).

SourceText:
Your home practice for this week will be to talk together with your teen about a ONE negative consequence and ONE positive consequence.

Consequences should be:
FAIR (not too harsh)
IMMEDIATE (do it straight away)
CONSISTENT (same every time)

Consequences should be:
FAIR (not too harsh)
IMMEDIATE (do it straight away)
CONSISTENT (same every time)

SourceText:
Negative Behaviour: Coming home after the agreed hour. 

Negative Consequence: Cannot see friends the next day. 

Negative Behaviour: Talking rudely. 

Negative Consequence: Write a letter of apology. 
 
Positive Behaviour: Helping out with shopping. 

Positive Consequence: 30 minutes extra of loved activity of their choice.  

Positive Behaviour: Helping look after younger siblings. 

Positive Consequence: One hour of extra time with friends on the weekend.

SourceText: All families experience crises. When we prepare together and know where to get help BEFORE something bad happens, we can overcome any crisis.

SourceText:
Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is dealing with crises.

Crises may occur anywhere. Crises may occur anytime. Therefore, it is important as a family to have plans in place should any family member find themselves in a crisis situation. 

It is important to have plans so that every family member may feel protected. 

When we are dealing with crises, remember to take a pause, breathe, and keep yourself calm. That will help you to deal with crises better.

Greetings, everyone.

Today's topic is dealing with crises.

Crises may occur anywhere. Crises may occur anytime. Therefore, it is important as a family to have plans in place should any family member find themselves in a crisis situation. 

It is important to have plans so that every family member may feel protected. 

When we are dealing with crises, remember to take a pause, breathe, and keep yourself calm. That will help you to deal with crises better.

Today our topic is positive instructions. 

It is important to give positive instructions to our children, because when we give them positive instructions they know and understand what we are expecting them to do, and they do it the way we want them to do it. 

So, at the end it keeps everyone happy.

Greetings, greetings everyone.

Today our topic is positive instructions. 

It is important to give positive instructions to our children, because when we give them positive instructions they know and understand what we are expecting them to do, and they do it the way we want them to do it. 

So, at the end it keeps everyone happy.

SourceText: Let’s do a thought experiment!

SourceText:
DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT 

What are you thinking about?
text:
DO NOT THINK ABOUT AN ELEPHANT 

What are you thinking about?

SourceText:
You probably DID think about an elephant...

‘Don’t do’ instructions make teens think about that thing. 

Sometimes they don’t understand what we DID want from them. 

Also they often don’t like being told not to do things (don’t we all?)

SourceText:

Teens will also feel more respected this way, and are more likely to listen.

SourceText: Positive instructions can work with your teen too!
text: Positive instructions can work with your teen too!

SourceText: GET REAL
text: GET REAL

SourceText: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.
text: Can your teen actually do what you are about to ask? It may be impossible for them to read quietly all day, but half an hour when you really need it is realistic.

SourceText: GET POSITIVE
text: GET POSITIVE

SourceText: Smile, look them in the eye, and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!
text: Smile, look them in the eye, and use positive words. Praise them as soon as they start to do what you ask!

SourceText: GET  CLEAR
text: GET  CLEAR

SourceText: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home in time’.
text: Often we know what we want in our head, but we don’t say it clearly enough. Say exactly what you want your teen to do. Try ‘please come home by 7pm’ instead of ‘come home in time’.

SourceText: Let's practice giving REAL, POSITIVE and CLEAR instructions. Practice will help you be successful with your teen!
text: Let's practice giving REAL, POSITIVE and CLEAR instructions. Practice will help you be successful with your teen!

SourceText:
Choose two people from your group:
* One person pretends to be a teenager
* The other pretends to be the teenager’s parent
* “Parent”: Give your “teen” a positive instruction with encouragement and praise
* “Teen”: Respond as you think a teen may respond to this 

Discuss together how that went:
* How did this make you feel as “parent” and as “teen”?
* Could you do anything better?

Give everyone a chance to be the “parent” and the “teen” if you can. Practice brings success!

Give everyone a chance to be the “parent” and the “teen” if you can. Practice brings success!

SourceText: Examples of positive instructions:
text: Examples of positive instructions:

SourceText:
* I like your music. Could you turn it down during dinner so that we can talk? Thank you – I really appreciate it. 
* That’s great music. Who is the singer? Please turn the music off when you come in the house. You can play it in your room quietly if you want. Thank you!

SourceText:
This week's home practice is to give your teen positive instructions.

Remember – GET REAL, GET POSITIVE, GET CLEAR = GET EXACTLY WHAT YOU WANT (as much as is possible with a teenager!)

SourceText:
Many families are stressed about money, especially if teens keep asking for things! 

When we make a budget together, we can agree how to spend AND save to prevent stress and work towards our family’s goals.
text:
Many families are stressed about money, especially if teens keep asking for things! 

When we make a budget together, we can agree how to spend AND save to prevent stress and work towards our family’s goals.

SourceText:
Greetings, everyone. 

Today's topic is family budgeting. 

It is important to create a budget, but it is even more important to create a budget involving the entire family. 

Doing it together helps increase the level of understanding of how you spend money as a family and how much you save for the family, and you can even come up with plans of how you can save as a family.

SourceText:
There are four steps for doing a family budget: 

Step 1: THINK
Step 2: CHOOSE
Step 3: BUILD
Step 4: PLAN

Let’s go through the steps together. You need:

- Papers (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and pens
- Stones or beans or anything with lots of bits to represent money
 
Take a minute to get these things before we start with the first step.

SourceText: Think about what we spend money on each month.
text: Think about what we spend money on each month.

SourceText:
* Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen. 
* Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month. 
* Write next to each picture how much each thing costs each month. (There is no need to share the numbers if you don’t want to.)
* Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

SourceText:
Talk together about your needs and wants

WANT: Something you can live without
NEED: Something you cannot live without
text:
Talk together about your needs and wants

WANT: Something you can live without
NEED: Something you cannot live without

SourceText:
People often don’t see things in the same way. When we talk about our needs and wants, we understand each other better and can make good choices together on how to spend our money.

Look at your lists of things you spend money on and discuss:
* Which are NEEDS that you can’t live without? Why?
* Which are WANTS which are nice to have but not essential? Why? 
* Which things could you try to spend less money on as a family?

SourceText: Make a budget as one big family!

SourceText:
* One person will volunteer to share his/her list (If no one volunteers you can make a new list together) 
* Take roles - some will be adults, some will be teens. 
* Decide what your income is for the month.
* Take some stones or beans or anything with lots of bits - this is your income for the month. 
(For example: If your income is @global.currency@local.monthly_income, and you have @local.number_of_beans beans, each bean is @global.currency@local.bean_value.)  
* Decide together what you will spend on what, and put the stones/objects on that image. 

Not sure about your decisions? Having trouble deciding between "needs" and "wants"? That’s totally fine!

text:
Great work, you have completed the first 3 steps! 

Let's see how @global.w_money_grandma made a plan with her money, just like you are doing:
note: The string @global.w_money_grandma should not be translated.

SourceText:
"I want the best future for my grandchildren, but I don’t know where to get the money. Loan sharks are dangerous and paying them back is so expensive. 

I should save, but that feels impossible!"
text:
"I want the best future for my grandchildren, but I don’t know where to get the money. Loan sharks are dangerous and paying them back is so expensive. 

I should save, but that feels impossible!"

SourceText: "My goal is to make sure my grandson can go to high school and my granddaughter can reach her dream of university. How can I save a lot of money with the little money I have?"
text: "My goal is to make sure my grandson can go to high school and my granddaughter can reach her dream of university. How can I save a lot of money with the little money I have?"

SourceText: "I know - let’s start with a plan! First, let me make a budget – a plan for how I can save my money. Then I will save just a little bit of money at a time – I will even join a savings and loans group."
text: "I know - let’s start with a plan! First, let me make a budget – a plan for how I can save my money. Then I will save just a little bit of money at a time – I will even join a savings and loans group."

SourceText: "I should also speak with my grandchildren to choose things that we can spend just a little bit less on each week. They will help me think of things we want but don’t need."
text: "I should also speak with my grandchildren to choose things that we can spend just a little bit less on each week. They will help me think of things we want but don’t need."

SourceText:
A few years later:

"Look, we reached our dreams! I didn’t borrow any money from friends or loan sharks. By saving a tiny bit each week, I managed to pay for @global.w_money_teen_boy’s high school and save some money for @global.w_money_teen_girl’s university. I am so proud of this.”

SourceText: Emergencies can happen in any family. Saving some money for these emergencies BEFORE they happen prevents a lot of sudden worry and stress!

SourceText: Let's talk about different ways we can save.
text: Let's talk about different ways we can save.

SourceText:
Discuss together: 
* In which different ways can we save?  
* What are the advantages and disadvantages of each savings option? 

Understanding each option well will help you to decide what is the best saving option for your family.  

Whatever savings plan you choose, it will really help your family move forward!

SourceText:
Make a budget again - this time WITH your teen and family! 

This is an important and fun thing to do with your family - it takes about 30 minutes.

Making a budget together helps teens understand that we all need to make hard decisions sometimes - but that it helps us have enough money at the end of the month and realise our goals!

Budgets have helped  millions of families.

SourceText:
Praise is a powerful parenting skill.

If we praise our teens when they do something well, we will see them do more and more positive things!

Praise is a powerful parenting skill.

SourceText:
Greetings everyone. 

Our topic today is about praise. 

It is good to praise our children when they've done good because when we do that, they will do more of that good behavior we want to see. 

And let's not forget to praise ourselves when we do good too!

SourceText:
Share with each other:

* When last did someone thank you or say you did something great? 
* How did it make you feel? 
* How does it feel if you are not thanked or praised for what you do? 

We usually don’t get thanked or praised enough as parents. Maybe you can give your teens the right example and praise them first when they do something well!

Teens can spend a lot of time outside the house or online, where it is harder for us to keep them safe. 

Talking together about safe and unsafe places, and how to prevent problems, really helps!

SourceText:
Greetings, everyone. 

Today our topic is teen safety. 

It is our responsibility as parents to keep our teens safe at all times. We need to ensure that our teenagers are safe in the communities that we live in. It is our responsibility that we make them aware of the safe and unsafe areas in the communities. 

It is also our responsibility to ensure that they understand the dangers that they might be exposed to when they are online. That way our teenagers will be responsible and be able to make right decisions to keep themselves safe too.
text:
Greetings, everyone. 

Today our topic is teen safety. 

It is our responsibility as parents to keep our teens safe at all times. We need to ensure that our teenagers are safe in the communities that we live in. It is our responsibility that we make them aware of the safe and unsafe areas in the communities. 

It is also our responsibility to ensure that they understand the dangers that they might be exposed to when they are online. That way our teenagers will be responsible and be able to make right decisions to keep themselves safe too.

SourceText: Let's talk about our teens' online safety.
text: Let's talk about our teens' online safety.

SourceText: What are some of the online risks for teens these days?
text: What are some of the online risks for teens these days?

SourceText:
* Adults use social media, gaming and messaging apps and websites to meet teenagers and persuade them to do sexual things 
* People put things online to make us hurt other people – like making violence seem cool, or hating people from another race or country
* People put things online to persuade teenagers to hurt themselves or commit suicide
* Teenagers share sexy videos or photos or information about themselves, and people show it to others or use it to upset them
* People can often be nasty to teenagers online – they feel like they can bully people safely

To keep our teens safe, we need to understand the dangerous situations they could get into!

Let’s make two maps together of safe and unsafe places:
* A map of our community
* A map of apps/websites we use online

Let’s make these maps as a group now. 

You’ll do the same with your teen as home practice this week.

SourceText:
Make an AMNESTY agreement. If something happens that makes them upset, uncomfortable or scared, they can talk to you and you won’t get angry or punish them, even if they were doing something wrong.

Remember the story about Safety Amnesty? See it again here.

SourceText:
We often don’t look after ourselves enough. But this is so important, especially as a parent! 

Reducing our stress and treating ourselves well helps us AND our teenagers.
text:
We often don’t look after ourselves enough. But this is so important, especially as a parent! 

Reducing our stress and treating ourselves well helps us AND our teenagers.

SourceText:
Greetings, everyone. 

Today's topic is self-care. 

There are times where we experience challenging times, where we face problems and do not know what to do. It is important to take care of ourselves to learn the techniques of how we can keep ourselves calm in case problems, challenges or issues come up. 

When we are calm we are in a good state to think positively and come up with positive solutions to any challenges we may be facing.

SourceText:
Every family faces challenges, but when we work together we can deal with problems in an effective and peaceful way. 

What a great skill for your teen to learn too!
text:
Every family faces challenges, but when we work together we can deal with problems in an effective and peaceful way. 

What a great skill for your teen to learn too!

SourceText:
Greetings, everyone. 

Today's topic is problem solving. 

We all know that in life there are times where we face problems, and we all know in a way that when we find ourselves in these situations, it is difficult to think of immediate positive solutions. 

Therefore, it is important that when we are facing problems we take a pause, we breathe, keep calm and think of problem-solving skills that we may use. 

Remember to include our teenagers when we are solving problems. This will help them to become responsible and learn how to solve their own problems in the future.
text:
Greetings, everyone. 

Today's topic is problem solving. 

We all know that in life there are times where we face problems, and we all know in a way that when we find ourselves in these situations, it is difficult to think of immediate positive solutions. 

Therefore, it is important that when we are facing problems we take a pause, we breathe, keep calm and think of problem-solving skills that we may use. 

Remember to include our teenagers when we are solving problems. This will help them to become responsible and learn how to solve their own problems in the future.

With teenagers – and in life – unexpected problems come up. 

Here are 4 problem-solving steps to do together.

text:
Practice together on a problem you have now. One of you is the parent and one the teen. 

Praise and encourage each other – we are proud of you! 

Remember the steps: 
KNOW IT - SOLVE IT - TRY IT - TEST IT

SourceText:
Teach your teenagers the four steps of problem-solving:
KNOW IT - SOLVE IT - TRY IT - TEST IT 

Use these steps together when a problem comes up!

When something bad happens, we often get upset and blame. But what our teens really need is someone to help find solutions together. Listen to them, accept how they see and feel things, and thank them for trusting you.

Teaching your teen how to deal with problems will help them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

SourceText: We know how stressful it is to bring up teenagers in these times. Learning to manage your stress helps you - and your family.
text: We know how stressful it is to bring up teenagers in these times. Learning to manage your stress helps you - and your family.

SourceText:
Greetings everyone. 

Today's topic is managing stress. 

It is important to know how to manage our stress. At times our children can behave in ways that makes us feel stressed and us as parents can make our children feel stressed too. 

So, it is important to notice when we feel stressed and take a pause and breathe. That will help you manage your stress.

SourceText:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_1: “Can I have money to buy some airtime?”  

@global.w_stress_male_caregiver (taking a breath): “I’m sorry son. I had a difficult day today. The boss fired me.”
text:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_1: “Can I have money to buy some airtime?”  

@global.w_stress_male_caregiver (taking a breath): “I’m sorry son. I had a difficult day today. The boss fired me.”

SourceText:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_1: “Oh no!  I need a new school uniform.”  

@global.w_stress_male_caregiver: “I’ll try, son, And your @global.w_stress_female_caregiver’s job will help us get by while I look for another job.”
text:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_1: “Oh no!  I need a new school uniform.”  

@global.w_stress_male_caregiver: “I’ll try, son, And your @global.w_stress_female_caregiver’s job will help us get by while I look for another job.”

SourceText:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_1: “I can help out with looking for work, too, @global.w_stress_male_caregiver?”  

@global.w_stress_male_caregiver: “No it’s okay, @global.w_stress_teen_boy_1. I appreciate your offer. The most important thing is that you work hard at school. Thanks for listening to me.”

SourceText: Safety Amnesty
text: Safety Amnesty

SourceText:
Think back to when you were a teenager. 

Was there ever a time when you were in danger but you couldn’t tell your family because they would have been angry?

This ALMOST happened to @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2 and @global.w_stress_teen_girl! Let’s have a look:
text:
Think back to when you were a teenager. 

Was there ever a time when you were in danger but you couldn’t tell your family because they would have been angry?

This ALMOST happened to @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2 and @global.w_stress_teen_girl! Let’s have a look:

SourceText:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_2: "Don’t tell the adults, but I’m going to bar with my friends tonight" 

@global.w_stress_teen_girl: "Have fun! I’ve told them I’m staying with my girlfriend, but I’m actually going to a cool party"
text:
@global.w_stress_teen_boy_2: "Don’t tell the adults, but I’m going to bar with my friends tonight" 

@global.w_stress_teen_girl: "Have fun! I’ve told them I’m staying with my girlfriend, but I’m actually going to a cool party"

SourceText: @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2: "I think they are dealing drugs. We could all get arrested. But I can’t tell my parents – they’ll be so angry"
text: @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2: "I think they are dealing drugs. We could all get arrested. But I can’t tell my parents – they’ll be so angry"
note: The string @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2 should not be translated.

SourceText: @global.w_stress_teen_girl: "I’m scared. Everyone is too drunk to drive me home. This boy says he’ll take me but he wants us to go to his house first. I can’t tell my parents – I lied about coming to this party."
text: @global.w_stress_teen_girl: "I’m scared. Everyone is too drunk to drive me home. This boy says he’ll take me but he wants us to go to his house first. I can’t tell my parents – I lied about coming to this party."
note: The string @global.w_stress_teen_girl should not be translated.

SourceText:
These are dangerous situations! Thankfully, @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2 and @global.w_stress_teen_girl then remembered what @global.w_stress_parent told them:  

"I care about your safety more than anything. If you are ever upset, or scared, you can always call me for help, or tell me about it. 

Just say 'SAFETY AMNESTY'. I promise that I will try my best to help and I won’t be angry – even if you are doing something you shouldn't."
text:
These are dangerous situations! Thankfully, @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2 and @global.w_stress_teen_girl then remembered what @global.w_stress_parent told them:  

"I care about your safety more than anything. If you are ever upset, or scared, you can always call me for help, or tell me about it. 

Just say 'SAFETY AMNESTY'. I promise that I will try my best to help and I won’t be angry – even if you are doing something you shouldn't."

SourceText: @global.w_stress_teen_girl: "@global.w_stress_parent, it’s a safety amnesty. Can you come and pick me up? I really need a lift home."
text: @global.w_stress_teen_girl: "@global.w_stress_parent, it’s a safety amnesty. Can you come and pick me up? I really need a lift home."

SourceText: @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2: "@global.w_stress_parent, safety amnesty. I think my friends are in trouble. I don’t want to stop being their friend, but I’m worried. Can we talk?"
text: @global.w_stress_teen_boy_2: "@global.w_stress_parent, safety amnesty. I think my friends are in trouble. I don’t want to stop being their friend, but I’m worried. Can we talk?"

SourceText: BREATHE. Slowly. Pause.
text: BREATHE. Slowly. Pause.

SourceText: Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out five times. It will calm you, and give you a chance to think.
text: Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out five times. It will calm you, and give you a chance to think.

SourceText: SHARE how you feel
text: SHARE how you feel

SourceText: This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry, or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress.
text: This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry, or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress.

SourceText: SHOW them you care
text: SHOW them you care

SourceText: This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say ‘I understand’. It can change everything.
text: This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say ‘I understand’. It can change everything.

SourceText: SEEK the positive
text: SEEK the positive

SourceText: Can you and your teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?
text: Can you and your teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?

SourceText: If all else fails, breathe. You can do this.
text: If all else fails, breathe. You can do this.

SourceText: There are two home practices for this week.
text: There are two home practices for this week.

SourceText:
Whenever you are feeling stressed or upset: take five breaths in and out before you react. 

And when you're both calm, share with your teen how you feel.
text:
Whenever you are feeling stressed or upset: take five breaths in and out before you react. 

And when you're both calm, share with your teen how you feel.

SourceText: That’s wonderful! Well done for spending time together. It lays the foundation for a great relationship with your teen!
text: That’s wonderful! Well done for spending time together. It lays the foundation for a great relationship with your teen!

SourceText: Good for you! One-on-one time shows your teens they are important to you. It really makes a difference!
text: Good for you! One-on-one time shows your teens they are important to you. It really makes a difference!

SourceText: Wonderful! Spending time with your teen may make your teen more willing to help out more often. You are doing great!
text: Wonderful! Spending time with your teen may make your teen more willing to help out more often. You are doing great!

SourceText: Well done! One-on-one time with your teen gives you a chance to learn more about your teen’s interests and abilities. You are a star!
text: Well done! One-on-one time with your teen gives you a chance to learn more about your teen’s interests and abilities. You are a star!

SourceText: Excellent job! Spending time together helps to build a strong and positive relationship between you and your teen.
text: Excellent job! Spending time together helps to build a strong and positive relationship between you and your teen.

SourceText: Sometimes it will be easy and fun to spend time with your teens, and sometimes it will be more challenging. Spending time together will greatly improve your relationship; well done for trying!
text: Sometimes it will be easy and fun to spend time with your teens, and sometimes it will be more challenging. Spending time together will greatly improve your relationship; well done for trying!

SourceText: Sorry to hear that it was difficult for you to spend time with your teen. We all have challenges sometimes. Just be patient with yourself and your teen - things will get better. Well done for trying!
text: Sorry to hear that it was difficult for you to spend time with your teen. We all have challenges sometimes. Just be patient with yourself and your teen - things will get better. Well done for trying!

SourceText: Great to hear it went well; you are a star!
text: Great to hear it went well; you are a star!

SourceText: Wonderful! You deserve all the happy times!
text: Wonderful! You deserve all the happy times!

SourceText: Sorry that this was difficult for you. You are a star for trying!
text: Sorry that this was difficult for you. You are a star for trying!

SourceText: Amazing to hear it made you feel good! Keep up the great work. Your teen is learning so much from you!
text: Amazing to hear it made you feel good! Keep up the great work. Your teen is learning so much from you!

SourceText: Talking about how we feel can be difficult at first, but you and your teen will get used to it. Keep trying, and you will see the positive results!
text: Talking about how we feel can be difficult at first, but you and your teen will get used to it. Keep trying, and you will see the positive results!

SourceText: Great to hear it went well. Talking about your finances together really makes your family stronger!
text: Great to hear it went well. Talking about your finances together really makes your family stronger!

SourceText: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!
text: Sorry to hear it was difficult for you. Well done for trying!

SourceText: Great to hear it went well! Consistent rules help make our teens feel secure, and keep them safe!
text: Great to hear it went well! Consistent rules help make our teens feel secure, and keep them safe!

SourceText: Sorry that this has been difficult. Creating rules together requires some practice but it's worth it!
text: Sorry that this has been difficult. Creating rules together requires some practice but it's worth it!

SourceText: Great to hear it went well!
text: Great to hear it went well!

SourceText: Sorry that this was difficult. Setting consequences together will make your teen want to follow the rules more often!
text: Sorry that this was difficult. Setting consequences together will make your teen want to follow the rules more often!

SourceText: Sorry that this was hard. Sometimes we just have to keep trying. Find a time when you and your teen are calm and try again to talk through a problem using the four steps of problem-solving. Together, you can do so much!
text: Sorry that this was hard. Sometimes we just have to keep trying. Find a time when you and your teen are calm and try again to talk through a problem using the four steps of problem-solving. Together, you can do so much!

SourceText: Great to hear it went well! Talking about risks and support options prevents problems and really helps to keep your teen safe.
text: Great to hear it went well! Talking about risks and support options prevents problems and really helps to keep your teen safe.

SourceText: Sorry that this was hard. Mapping risks and places to get support can be challenging and emotional. It really does help to keep your teen safe!
text: Sorry that this was hard. Mapping risks and places to get support can be challenging and emotional. It really does help to keep your teen safe!

SourceText: Sorry that it didn’t go so well. This is not easy to do. Try to sit down and discuss it with your teen again. Also, is there someone your teen trusts who could join you in the discussion with your teen?
text: Sorry that it didn’t go so well. This is not easy to do. Try to sit down and discuss it with your teen again. Also, is there someone your teen trusts who could join you in the discussion with your teen?

SourceText: Great to hear it went well! Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.
text: Great to hear it went well! Getting consequences right helps teens behave better and makes family life calmer.

SourceText: Great to hear it went well! When your teen learns how to solve problems, they can use that skill their whole life. What a gift!
text: Great to hear it went well! When your teen learns how to solve problems, they can use that skill their whole life. What a gift!

SourceText: Welcome to ParentApp. Click here to start your journey!

SourceText: Hope you are feeling OK. Parenting is hard, but it’s never too late to start again with your teenager. Your first parenting workshop is ready for you! Click here to start your ParentApp journey!
text: Hope you are feeling OK. Parenting is hard, but it’s never too late to start again with your teenager. Your first parenting workshop is ready for you! Click here to start your ParentApp journey!

SourceText: Hi! Is everything OK? It seems you haven’t opened ParentApp lately. Why don’t you give it a try? Millions of parents have found these materials helpful. We are still here to support you.
text: Hi! Is everything OK? It seems you haven’t opened ParentApp lately. Why don’t you give it a try? Millions of parents have found these materials helpful. We are still here to support you.

SourceText: Hello again! It’s never too late to use ParentApp and get tailored parenting support. Why don’t you give it a try when you are commuting to work or when the food is cooking? Millions of parents found our materials helpful.
